item.title: 🇲🇽 🇨🇦 a Pause
item.description:
<p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; When I was about to leave for Canada, an incident happened. My US visa expired, which could not allow me to transfer my flight in the US. So, I canceled my flight and tried to find a solution. Since I have arranged all my flights, it would be costly if I postpone any part of my trips too much. Luckily, I got a ticket to Cancun, Mexico, and another one from Cancun to Montreal. My Canadian Visa helped me stay one night in Mexico. I had to admit that traveling cost in Cancun was high! Uber was not available at the airport. Taxi to hotel island was expensive, and so was food. However, the beach was clean, and sea water was pure. No doubt that people in the US always took a holiday here. I have never been to Mexico before. All I knew were drug business, Aztek historical spots and illegal immigration stuff. Visiting Mexico helped me know this country a little bit and revise some stereotypes.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; On the next day, I left for Montreal. I planned to visit a couple who were my friends during undergraduate. They lived in Montreal for PhD. I lived at a dorm where ten people shared. I wandered around the city and discovered a lot of French elements on streets.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Then, I took a train to Toronto where I planned to meet Cong and visit Niagara Fall together. However, her flight was canceled due to storm. So, I took a train to Niagara myself. It is so big that the moisture caused by the Fall formed a microenvironment around it. Basically, it was a sunny day, but it rained nearby.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Staying for five days, I well-prepared for my next journey: Africa!!! That was the most expected part in my tour!</p>

item.title: 🇵🇪 Respect Mountain
🇨🇴 One Week of Solitude
item.description: <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Cuban travel left me with remarkable memory, attractive nature touched me greatly. I was sure that I would be back there sooner or later. That will be interesting to observe differences years later. Then, I headed for my next spot, Colombia. Seven days in Colombia was not a long trip, but that did not mean a boring experience. Hispanic culture and their history are way different from the others. No doubt, Marquez named “A hundred years of Solitude”.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <em>Bogota: Potential danger</em><br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Staying at small town in the States for a long time, I had to say skyscrapers were unfamiliar for me. Bogota was similar with other cities which are segregated greatly. The north district is safe, but the south is not. I spent a whole day walking around the city, from my hotel to different museums. I planned four days here with three museum visits which were the national museum, gold museum, and Botero museum. The national museum shows its history and how Colombian people united. I love history, but South American history was blank in my mind. It was interesting that Colombian history was so isolated. There were a lot of Inka Empire, only a period of colonization by Spain. Therefore, the national museum was kind of boring because it just explained where Colombia was from, and how people united. The second museum, Gold Museum, was more interesting. It showed how people used gold to decorate and how jewelry designed and made. However, an earthquake interrupted my plan. I did not finish this museum tour, and Botero museum neither. That was my first earthquake experience. Nearly 6.0 magnitude made the whole building shake strongly. At the first few seconds, I was confused slightly, for I had no sense of earthquake. Then, I was aware that the earthquake happened, and I moved to the corner for safety. However, I did not leave the museum directly and expected to resume my visit shortly. Staff asked me to leave because the museum would be closed. While, due to the earthquake, I made a friend who were next to me during the earthquake. Since, my visit was interrupted, I bought her a coffee and wandered around the city for a while. She was supposed to take a bus to her home at night, but the bus was not on service. On the next day, I climbed to a mountain where I got a bird view of the city, big but polluted. The temperature was comfortable, or even slightly chilly. The whole city is surrounded by mountains. In the afternoon, I walked around the city with my new friend, where we found Marquez Plaza, a music show by university, and a party to celebrate the establishment of Bogota for 500 years. At night, Bogota was a little bit dangerous. Pedestrians told me not take my phone outside my pocket due to theft. There were some drug activities at night, so it was even hard for me to take an Uber. Especially for the south district, drivers would not access there. Somehow, I was shocked by it.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <em>Medellin: Drug history</em><br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Four days were short for visiting a city. I moved my feet to visit another one, Medellin. It was famous for its drug history and its cable transportation. As an urban planner, Medellin is famous, which is a good example of transportation plan. People in slums spread across mountains, so it used to be difficult for them to access to resources like education, transportation, or even healthcare. Therefore, cable cars connect people in slum with city.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Before I went to Medellin, I did some research. I discovered the wealthy districts where they have lower crime cases. When I landed, I found the city was poorer than Bogota, but as the uber driving, the city became beautiful and clean, a totally different environment. Near my hotel, I found a Korean restaurant. The boss was graduated from UIUC as well, and surprisingly he could even spoke Chinese. On the next day, I visited Comuna 13, which is the most famous slum. It was totally different though. People were doing business along the street, and it was extremely crowded. Dance and music were everywhere. They had a lot of street painting on the wall where you can obtain small holes by bullets. That district used to be the base of gangsters and criminals. Children over 15 were forced to transport drugs for them, and they shot guns almost every day. As a guy without any memory of chaos, that was horrible and hard to imagine how people struggled for living. During my stay, I joined a city walk. My tour guide shared his experience. When he was young, he had to hide behind walls on his way to school, and his sister was murdered by criminals. There were a lot of crimes, and people suffered from drugs. During city walk, I observed a man and a woman taking a drug in front of me, a theft stealing a phone, and a girl lying on the chair with an extremely weird pose.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Overall, Colombia is a complicated country. Its history was full of pain, colonization and drug, but they have kind people and comfortable environment.</p>

item.title: 🇨🇺 Mojito,Cigar and Salsa

🌍 New Advanture
一些关于学业的思索
item.description: <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 在申请工作之余，一直在思考未来的发展，不同的选择将会有不同的结果。简言之，是否继续读书、是否本行业，组合下来有四种：两个硕士毕业，本专业工作，我会立刻选择上海规划院，接着以考公或者考职称的方式晋升，最终兼顾自己的工作和公司；换行业就业，可以借着大数据发展的小红利，以后从事企业中的数据工作，估计不会有大成就，也不会有十分稳定的工作环境；博士换方向，或许是一件无法实现的事；博士坚持城市规划或者地理信息，在本专业中专注数据研发方向，集中在空间治理，未来毕业可以在大企业做研发岗，例如地图研发，或者在高校科研单位做科研。这些选择毋庸置疑，最后一个适合我，躺平不适合我，放弃原本的知识积累也是不理智。<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 高校的选择，目前港大是最好的选择，排名高科研水平高，未来就业前景也会很棒。同时，国内外的资源我都可以利用，即使未来选择在香港生活，我也可以承受其成本压力。那么，就继续努力吧！</p>
